markers.label: Clenched Fists (Tense Posture)
markers.feedback: Starting with clenched fists can make you appear tense or defensive. Try beginning with your hands relaxed at your sides to project a more open and confident demeanor.

markers.label: Lack of clear structure
markers.feedback: The presentation feels improvised and lacks a clear beginning, middle, and end. Try creating a simple outline before you record: an engaging hook, 1-2 key points with examples, and a concluding summary. This will greatly improve the logical flow.

markers.label: Speaking pace too slow
markers.feedback: Your initial pace is quite slow, which might cause the audience to lose focus. Try to inject a bit more energy and speed into your opening to grab their attention from the start.

markers.label: Monotone delivery
markers.feedback: Your pitch remains very flat during the start of your speech, which can make it sound robotic. Try varying your vocal pitch to emphasize key ideas and emotions, which will help keep your audience engaged.

markers.label: Low energy
markers.feedback: Overall, the energy in your voice is very low, making it sound like you're disengaged from your own story. Try speaking a bit louder and with more conviction. Projecting your voice will naturally bring more energy and presence to your delivery.

markers.label: Unexplained key points
markers.feedback: You state that the team didn't make it to worlds, but you don't explain why or share any details about the experience. Supporting your main points with brief examples or stories will make your presentation much more engaging and informative.

markers.label: Awkward pause
markers.feedback: This 4-second pause is quite long and interrupts the flow of your presentation. If you need to gather your thoughts, a shorter, more natural pause of 1-2 seconds is more effective.

markers.label: Stiff Posture
markers.feedback: Your posture is very still and symmetrical, which can look a bit rigid. Allow for some natural, subtle movement to appear more relaxed and engaging for your audience.

markers.label: Lack of emphasis
markers.feedback: You're stating a very disappointing outcome, but the delivery doesn't convey that emotion. Try putting more stress on key phrases like "did not make it to worlds" and "really unfortunate" to add emotional weight and impact.

markers.label: Fidgeting (Self-Soothing)
markers.feedback: Touching your hair, even briefly, can be a distracting gesture. Practice keeping your hands away from your face and hair to maintain a focused and professional presence.

markers.label: Abrupt and unclear conclusion
markers.feedback: The presentation's pace suddenly accelerates and ends without a clear summary or final thought. Plan a strong closing sentence to wrap up your message. A good conclusion reinforces your main idea and leaves a lasting impression.

markers.label: Speaking pace too fast
markers.feedback: Your pace accelerates dramatically here, making it difficult for listeners to follow along. Remember to take breaths and focus on clear enunciation, even when you're speaking quickly.

markers.label: Rushed pacing
markers.feedback: Your speaking pace accelerates significantly here, which can make your words hard to follow. Remember to take breaths and maintain a deliberate pace to ensure your audience understands your message clearly.

transcript: I will now talk about my robotics team. We did not make it. We did not make it to worlds. That that that that is really unfortunate. And at the end of the day... we didn't really have any good experiences and it was really bad and I really didn't have any fun it was horrible it was horrible it was horrible and then...
